body.p: To integrate SolidFire storage with Helion OpenStack 2.0, you must configure the SolidFire storage array as a Cinder backend. This is done by modifying the cinder.conf.j2 file. In this configuration file you will create an Internet Small Computer Systems Interface (iSCSI) cluster. iSCSI is an Internet Protocol (IP)-based storage networking standard for linking data storage facilities.

ol.li: Log in to the lifecycle manager.
In a text editor, open the following file: ~/helion/my_cloud/config/cinder/cinder.conf.j2
To create a SolidFire backend, in the enabled_backends section add the following text: # Configure the enabled back-ends enabled_backends=SolidFire_iSCSI

In the same file, create a new SolidFire iSCSI cluster section and fill the values used in your environment as shown in the following code sample: # SolidFire Section [SolidFire_iSCSI] volume_driver = san_ip = san_login = san_password = sf_emulate_512 = volume_backend_name = # end solidfire
Sample SolidFire iSCI section:# SolidFire Section [SolidFire_iSCSI] volume_driver = cinder.volume.drivers.solidfire.SolidFireDriver san_ip = 10.2.17.252 san_login = openstack san_password = temp123 sf_emulate_512 = True volume_backend_name = solidfire # end solidfire
To commit your configuration changes to a local git repository, run: $ cd ~/helion/hos/ansible git add -A git commit -m "<Added SolidFire to Cinder Backend Storage>"
To use an ansible playbook to run the configuration processor, run: #cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
To use an ansible playbook to create a deployment directory, run: #cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
To complete the configuration, run: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts cinder-reconfigure.yml

body.p: For more on configuring SolidFire, use the SolidFire Documentation Resources list.
